Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative research: Quantifying the ecosystem-wide impacts of a strong interactor in African watersheds
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will initiate a collaborative research effort by ecologists, biogeochemists, and ecohydrologists at the University of California at Berkeley and Princeton University to study how the common hippopotamus affects ecosystems - and how change to these ecosystems in turn affects the hippopotamus. Remarkably little is known about the importance of the common hippopotamus to the ecosystems that they inhabit, despite the fact that they are recognized to be a vulnerable and declining species. Hippopotamus rest in rivers and shallow lakes during the day and then emerge at night to feed on land. By virtue of these movements these large herbivores transfer vast quantities of nutrients and energy across the boundary between aquatic and terrestrial ecosystems. These connections are likely to have a major influence on ecological properties and processes in each type of ecosystem. The project will quantify the movement ecology of hippopotamus, the rates at which they vector nutrients across ecosystems, the impacts that these transfers have upon the ecology of recipient ecosystems, and how river flow and rainfall influence these ecological phenomena.

This work will extend our general understanding of how transfers of material and energy influence the ecology of entire landscapes, how closely neighboring ecosystems are linked to one another, and how physical forcing determines the nature and importance of these connections. In addition to these important scientific contributions, this project will provide training for national and international postdoctoral researchers, involve undergraduates in research, generate creative science media for the general public, and support science outreach programs in educationally underserved rural settings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project we investigated the role that the common hippopotamus plays in shaping the ecology of the ecosystems with which it interacts. With hippopotamus declining rapidly across Africa, this work served the dual purpose of advancing our pure scientific understanding of the ecology of this understudied species and generating applied products that help us better interpret the significance of hippopotamus declines.

We discovered several important new pathways by which hippopotamus influence watersheds and terrestrial ecosystems, notably: 1) they vector nutrients into aquatic ecosystems that are used by consumers like economically and socially important fish species and 2) they substantially alter plant community and structure in the near-river regions where they feed. We determined that these effects of hippopotamus are strongly regulated by regional hydrology – meaning that shifts in water dynamics, such as those engendered by climate change, are highly likely to reshape the future influence of this important species. Our work uncovered first of its kind information of the movement biology and spatial ecology of hippopotamus, science that will be instrumental in better conserving this species and thoughtfully managing conflict between hippopotamus and people.

In addition to peer-reviewed scientific publications, other key products from this research include: 1) training opportunities for three postdoctoral scholars, one PhD student, one masters student, and multiple undergraduate students, 2) the creation of a live web cam that streams footage of our primary hippopotamus research that has received more than one million hits, 3) science education/outreach activities associated with this research that reached over 700 students and community members in rural Kenya, 4) the production of a short film showcasing key research findings, 5) sharing of our science with general audiences on BBC, the National Geographic Channel, and Science Magazine, 6) the instrumentation and public release of data on river flow from the strategically important Ewaso Nyiro River, and 7) fostering of new scientific collaborations between US researchers and colleagues at University of Nairobi, National Museums of Kenya, and Kenya Wildlife Service.
